Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Conversion of Carbon Dioxide and Water Using Visible Light and Nanostructured Ruthenium
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to utilize the products of combustion in conjunction with metal nanoparticles to create a cyclic reaction series, much like nature's photosynthesis. The impact of this research is far-reaching, as this technique could allow for the replacement of gasoline removed from the Earth's crust as a fuel source. A precursor to many other chemicals, naphthalene is the simplest polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon. In today's industry, it is removed from coal tar, and to a lesser degree, petroleum, during the various refining and distillation steps. Research performed by our lab group has demonstrated that certain nanostructured metal particles can convert carbon dioxide and water into gasoline using visible light. Recent research has demonstrated that naphthalene can be produced with a cobalt catalyst when methanol is used instead of water. These methods are significantly cleaner than the refining and distillation steps that are currently used, as well as being able to produce target compounds depending on the simple starting materials. This project will expand upon the known metals that can be used to perform these conversions by using ruthenium instead of more common metals. This research will be conducted at the National University of Singapore under the invaluable mentorship of Dr. Boon Siang (Jason) Yeo.

Naphthalene and normal-alkane hydrocarbons are produced during the refining and distillation steps of coal tar and petroleum. Research performed by our lab group has demonstrated the ability of Fischer-Tropsch nanostructured metal particles to convert water and carbon dioxide into arrays of n-alkane hydrocarbons when exposed to visible light overnight. Recently we have discovered that when methanol is used instead of water in a cobalt-containing system, the single product of naphthalene results. This project will continue the work done previously to test ruthenium as the final Fischer-Tropsch metal in both water and methanol systems.

This award, under East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to utilize metal nanoparticles and visible light to catalytically remove the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, converting it into more valuable chemicals. Environmental analytical chemistry as a field is actively attempting to find alternate fuel sources without necessitating a complete restructuring of the energy infratstructure. This research aimed to create a cyclic reaction series in which an energy source would be used up to form the starting materials used to create the energy source. This phenomenon is termed "artificial photosynthesis" because it resembles nature's photosynthetic process.

In this research, metal nanoparticles are required for the reaction, as the surface plasmon resonance effect enhances the energy input into the system. This allows the bonds to break within the molecules and new bonds to form. In the time leading up to the project, the general reaction conditions were determined when methanol and carbon dioxide were used with nanostructured cobalt particles. However, the specific impact of each parameter were not known. Thus, work was performed during the project duration at the National University of Singapore under the mentorship of Dr. Boon Siang (Jason) Yeo to determine these purposes. 

Over the course of the project, it was important to garner a better understanding of the artificial photosynthesis process. The work performed expanded the knowledge about the reaction and the conditions required for it to proceed. In the stepwise removal of each parameter set forth in the synthesis and catalysis reactions, knowledge about the importance of each condition were determined. The most intriguing of these was that it was found that heat was a necessary component for the catalytic reaction to occur.
